title: 104_s956
content: The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is established to study the division of the United States into judicial circuits, review the structure of the Federal courts of appeals, particularly the ninth circuit, and make recommendations to the President and Congress for changes in circuit boundaries or structure to improve the efficiency of the Federal Courts of Appeal. The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is composed of eleven members appointed by various officials, with vacancies filled in the same manner. The Commission elects a Chair and Vice Chair from its members, with six members needed for a quorum. Compensation details are outlined in Section 3. Members of the Commission, whether government officials or private individuals, will be reimbursed for expenses incurred during the performance of their duties. Government officials will not receive additional compensation, while private members will receive $200 per day for their services. Personnel details are outlined in Section 4. The Commission may appoint an Executive Director who will receive compensation not exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Executive Director can appoint additional personnel as needed without following certain regulations, with compensation not exceeding the annual maximum rate for positions above GS-15. The Director can hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the highest General Schedule pay rates. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts will provide administrative and financial services for the Commission, while the Federal Judicial Center will provide research services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is authorized to request information from government departments and agencies to carry out its functions. It must submit a report to the President and Congress by February 28, 1997, and will terminate ninety days after. Up to $500,000 is authorized for appropriations to the Commission. The Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate must act on the report within sixty days of its transmission. The Senate passed the report on March 20, 1996.
